newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel economic leaders divided on budget cuts.
newsitem.headline: Israel economic leaders divided on budget cuts.

text.p: Finance Minister Dan Meridor and Bank of Israel Governor Jacob Frenkel clashed over the issue of budget cuts for 1997 at a conference of the Israel Management Institute on Wednesday.
"A 4.9 billion shekel cut will not be enough to realise the goals we have set in 1997," said Frenkel, stressing the need for further cuts in the coming year without specifyiny any numbers.
Meridor, in contrast, emphasised the political obstacles to pushing steeper cuts through parliament.
"I am not sure that everyone agrees to spending cuts," he said. "The real test by decision makers is not in theory but in implementation."
He did not speak of any additional cuts beyond the 4.9 billion already approved by the cabinet and to be presented to parliament next week.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, however, reiterated that 4.9 billion shekels -- equal to 3.2 percent of spending next year -- would not be sufficient.
"It's a very big reduction but it's not enough." he said, adding there would be "wider and harder cuts".
Further cuts, however, are not expected before parliament approves the 4.9 billion shekel cut, which it has until the end of the year to do.

Meridor attacked the central bank's tight monetary policy and said it had to be less focussed on just inflation. "Every element of policy, whether it is the budget, monetary policy or reform influences everything."
Defending his hardline policy Frenkel hinted that an expected slowdown in the economy would not soften his stand on interest rates.
He said the Bank of Israel would not adjust its goals to deal with problems such as unemployment as its main goal was to fight inflation.

Frenkel will announce interest rates for November next week. The key lending rate now stands at an annual 15.5 percent while inflation is running at a rate of 11 percent. Netanyahu himself has called for a reduction in interest rates.
Meridor also discounted the connection between economic growth and peace, saying: "Is peace a necessary condition for growth -- No."
He noted that during the 1991 Gulf War the Israeli economy grew very quickly.
